description: Borrowed from French morgue. The second sense developed from the first, via "a prison examination room", probably with reference to the haughty attitude of the jailers.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A supercilious or haughty attitude; arrogance.
examples: They being newcomers, free from the western morgue so soon caught by Oriental Europeans, were particularly civil to me, even wishing to mix me a strong draught; but I was not so fortunate with all on board.

entries.meaning: A building or room where dead bodies are kept before their proper burial or cremation, (now) particularly in legal and law enforcement contexts.
(archaic) The archive and background information division of a newspaper.
examples: Kwapil, Joseph F. (2 July 1921) "Librarian Talks of Newspaper Morgue", Fourth Estate page 5.
